Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Data collection and curation of SR-530 mudslide with small unmanned aerial vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This project conducts research on small unmanned aerial systems while protecting the safety of recovery workers who will be working at the 2014 SR530 mudslide near Oso, Washington, for at least the next year to remediate the site and repair the road. The flights also help increase the safety of residents along other portions of the Stillaguamish River. A small fixed-wing and a rotorcraft unmanned aerial system are used to conduct longitudinal surveys of the inaccessible region of the mudslide and river. The surveys in August and November, combined with earlier flights during the immediate response, capture the evolving state of the mudslide and river over time, validate the models of how the river and mudslide are expected to change over the seasons, refine new geological and hydrological models, and predict the potential for continuing sloughing and flooding that will impact residents and other sections of SR530 in the spring of 2015. The research is providing the robotics and cyber-physical systems communities with small unmanned aerial systems performance data under uncontrolled weather conditions, the human-robot interaction community with how users from different agencies interact with the robot data, and Big Data with datasets to explore how to best archive, curate, and visualize data over time. The research is guiding the design of new small unmanned aerial systems to support applications where rapid or cost-effective geospatial reconstruction of the situation is important, such as emergency response and critical infrastructure inspection.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This participatory research project advanced artificial intelligence for unmanned aerial systems and the science of Big Data while actively helping Snohomish County Department of Public Works understand the geology and hydrology of the 2014 SR530 Mudslide near Oso, Washington.  A PrecisionHawk Lancaster fixed wing UAS and a AirRobot 180 quadrotor UAS  were deployed to survey the complex topology at the toe of the mudslide and river, which was extremely dangerous to survey with a manned helicopter. The lessons learned from the project were incorporated into best practices now used by the United Nations and were applied to the 2015 Texas Memorial Day floods.

 

From a scientific perspective, the deployment permitted a unique side-by-side comparison between two aerodynamically and operationally different UAS. The two platforms had similar times of flight due to FAA restrictions on line of sight operations. In practice there were significant differences between these platforms that will impact the design of future UAS, autonomy, and overall economic growth of UAS. These differences are:

 

  • the human-robot interaction for missions needed for analysis: the fixed wing was optimized for tasking automated surveys but the operator could not view the camera output or hover and stare at objects that required further investigation, while the quadrotor could do both automated surveys and hover and stare.

 

  • the types of paths and path planning: the fixed wing’s paths needed to be planned as a set of stair step like horizontal planes to follow the hillside’s elevation and the quadrotor’s path needed to be a set of vertical planes. However, UAS path planners assume the ground is flat and do not support elevation changes.

 

  • the support for privacy and the appearance of privacy: the fixed wing sometimes had to fly over roads and beyond property lines in order to turn to come back for sensing, while the quadrotor could stay within a prescribed area and collect data.

 

The five days of field work produced nearly 1TB of data, much of the data was imagery and video collected over several days with different UAVs and supplemented with context photos, as well as field notes and robot performance log files. The volume and heterogeneity of the data posed major challenges for existing visualization tools, and suggests that tools to handle Big Data will be critical for emergency managers.

 

As part of this research effort, the PerCon visual knowledge base tool and workspace was used to explore better visualizations. A major addition was enabling it to handle GPS meta data to be used in generating appropriate spatial and spatiotemporal visualizations of data. It also had to be expanded to include streaming video and multiple video formats as well as PDFs.
